subsection.title: Subsets of the Real Numbers
subsection.p:
The numbers associated with points on a number line are called the real numbersreal numbers. The set of real numbers is denoted by \mathbb{R}. You are already familiar with several types, or subsets, of real numbers:
The set \mathbb{N} of naturalnatural numbers, or counting numberscounting numbers, as its name suggests, consists of the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4 , \ldots , where "\ldots" indicates that the list continues without end.
The set \mathbb{W} of whole numberswhole numbers consists of the natural numbers and zero: 0, 1, 2, 3 \ldots.
The set \mathbb{Z} of integersintegers consists of the natural numbers, their negatives, and zero: \ldots , -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, \ldots.
All of these numbers are subsets of the rational numbers.

subsection.title: Rational Numbers
subsection.p: A number that can be expressed as the quotient of two integers \dfrac{a}{b} where b\ne 0, is called a rational numberrational number. The integers are rational numbers, and so are common fractions. Some examples of rational numbers are 5, -2, 0, \dfrac{2}{9} , \sqrt{16}, and \dfrac{-4}{17} . The set of rational numbers is denoted by \mathbb{Q} .

subsection.title: Irrational Numbers
subsection.p: Some real numbers cannot be written in the form \dfrac{a}{b} , where a and b are integers. For example, the number \sqrt{2} is not equal to any common fraction. Such numbers are called irrational numbersirrational numbers. Examples of irrational numbers are \sqrt{15}, \pi, and -\sqrt[3]{7} .

The decimal form of an irrational number never terminates, and its digits do not follow a repeating pattern, so it is impossible to write down an exact decimal equivalent for an irrational number. However, we can obtain decimal approximations correct to any desired degree of accuracy by rounding off. A graphing calculator gives the decimal representation of \pi as 3.141592654. This is not the exact value of \pi, but for most calculations it is quite adequate.

The subsets of the real numbers are related as shown in . Every natural number is also a whole number, every whole number is an integer, every integer is a rational number, and every rational number is real. Also, every real number is either rational or irrational.

li.p: 2 is a natural number, a whole number, an integer, a rational number, and a real number.
\sqrt{15} is an irrational number and a real number.
The number \pi, whose decimal representation begins 3.14159\ldots is irrational and real.
3.14159 is a rational and real number (which is close but not exactly equal to \pi).

subsection.title: Properties of the Real Numbers
subsection.p:
These properties do not mention subtraction or division. But we can define subtraction and division in terms of addition and multiplication. For example, we can define the difference a-b as follows:
a - b = a + (-b)
where -b, the additive inverseadditive inverse (or oppositeopposite) of b, is the number that satisfies b + (-b) = 0 Similarly, we can define the quotient \dfrac{a}{b}: \frac{a}{b}=a\left(\frac{1}{b} \right) \hphantom{blank} (b\ne 0) where \dfrac{1}{b} , the multiplicative inversemultiplicative inverse (or reciprocalreciprocal) of b, is the number that satisfies b\cdot\frac{1}{b}=1 \hphantom{blank} (b\ne 0)
Division by zero is not defined.

statement.p:
Use the commutative and associative laws to simplify the computations.
24 + 18 + 6
4 \cdot 27\cdot 25

li.p:
Apply the commutative law of addition.
24 + 18 + 6 \amp = (24 + 6) + 18
\amp = 30 + 18 = 48

Apply the commutative law of multiplication.
4 \cdot 27\cdot 25 \amp = (4\cdot 25)\cdot 27
\amp = 100 \cdot 27 = 2700

subsection.title: Order Properties of the Real Numbers
subsection.p:
Real numbers obey properties about order, that is, properties about inequalities. The familiar inequality symbols, \lt and \gt, have the following properties:
If a and b are any real numbers, then one of three things is true: a \lt b, ~~\text{ or }~~ a\gt b, ~~\text{ or }~~ a = b
(Transitive property) For real numbers a, b, and c, \text{if } a \lt b ~\text{ and }~ b \lt c, ~\text{ then }~ a \lt c
We also have three properties that are useful for solving inequalities:
If a\lt b, then a+c\lt b+c.
If a\lt b and c\gt 0, then ac \lt bc.
If a\lt b and c\lt 0, then ac\gt bc.

li.p: If x\lt y and y\lt -2, then x\lt -2
